üå± Beginner Phase: Foundation

Weeks 1-4 | Understanding Software Development & GitHub Basics

Phase Overview

Welcome to the beginning of your GitHub journey! This phase establishes the foundation you need to understand how software development works and how GitHub fits into that process.

What You‚Äôll Learn

By the end of this phase, you‚Äôll understand: - How software teams plan, develop, and collaborate - The Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) and DevOps principles - Git version control fundamentals and workflows - GitHub.com platform features and navigation - Source Code Management (SCM) as a team process - Planning and collaboration tools (Issues, Projects, PRs)

Phase Context

Before: You‚Äôre an experienced CSM with strong customer skills but limited software development exposure.

After: You‚Äôll speak confidently about software development processes, navigate GitHub with ease, and guide customers through basic workflows.

Modules

üìò Module 1: Understanding Software Development & SDLC

Duration: 8-10 hours | Weeks: 1

Before diving into tools, understand the problem space: How do software teams work? What problems does GitHub solve?

Topics: - Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) methodologies - Agile, Scrum, and DevOps principles - Planning phase: Requirements, user stories, and specifications - GitHub‚Äôs role in modern software development - GitHub Well-Architected Framework introduction

Learning Outcomes: - Explain SDLC phases and common methodologies - Understand DevOps culture and practices - Identify where GitHub fits in the development workflow - Recognize planning artifacts (epics, user stories, acceptance criteria)

Start Module 1 ‚Üí

üìò Module 2: Git Fundamentals & Version Control

Duration: 10-12 hours | Weeks: 1-2

Master the foundation of all source code management: Git version control system.

Topics: - What is version control and why it matters - Git architecture: repositories, commits, branches - Essential Git commands (clone, add, commit, push, pull) - Branching strategies and workflows (Git Flow, GitHub Flow) - Merge conflicts and resolution - Commit best practices and commit messages

Learning Outcomes: - Create and manage Git repositories - Use branching effectively for feature development - Resolve merge conflicts confidently - Write clear, descriptive commit messages - Understand distributed version control concepts

Start Module 2 ‚Üí

üìò Module 3: GitHub.com Platform Essentials

Duration: 10-12 hours | Weeks: 2-3

Navigate GitHub.com confidently and master core collaboration features.

Topics: - GitHub account setup and profile optimization - Creating and managing repositories - Issues: Creating, labeling, assigning, and tracking - Projects: Planning boards and project management - Pull Requests: Creating, reviewing, and merging - GitHub CLI, Desktop, and Mobile - Wikis and GitHub Pages for documentation - Discussions and community features

Learning Outcomes: - Navigate GitHub.com interface efficiently - Create and manage repositories with proper settings - Use Issues and Projects for planning and tracking - Collaborate through Pull Requests and code reviews - Choose the right GitHub tool for each task (web, CLI, Desktop)

Start Module 3 ‚Üí

üìò Module 4: Source Code Management as a Process

Duration: 8-10 hours | Weeks: 3-4

Understand how SCM works in real teams: workflows, collaboration patterns, and best practices.

Topics: - Team collaboration workflows (forking, branching, PR workflows) - Code review culture and best practices - Branch protection rules and repository settings - CODEOWNERS and automated reviewer assignment - Commit signing and verification - Release management and semantic versioning - Team communication and notification management

Learning Outcomes: - Design appropriate workflows for different team sizes - Configure repository protection rules - Conduct effective code reviews - Manage releases and versions properly - Set up team notification strategies

Start Module 4 ‚Üí

Beginner Phase Milestone Project

üéØ Project: Collaborative Documentation Repository

Objective: Demonstrate mastery of beginner concepts by building a collaborative documentation repository for a fictional product team.

Requirements: 1. Create a repository with proper README, CONTRIBUTING, and CODE_OF_CONDUCT 2. Set up branch protection rules requiring PR reviews 3. Create a GitHub Project board with columns for documentation tasks 4. Open 5+ issues with proper labels, assignments, and descriptions 5. Submit 3+ pull requests with detailed descriptions and resolve review comments 6. Implement CODEOWNERS for different documentation sections 7. Create a release with changelog and semantic versioning 8. Document the workflow in a wiki or GitHub Pages site

Deliverables: - Live repository demonstrating all requirements - 10-minute presentation walking through your workflow - Written reflection on lessons learned

Assessment Criteria: - Repository structure and documentation quality (25%) - Proper use of Issues and Projects (25%) - PR process and code review interactions (25%) - Branch protection and release management (15%) - Presentation clarity and insights (10%)

Phase Completion Checklist

Before moving to the Intermediate phase, ensure you can:

  • Explain the SDLC and DevOps principles to a customer
  • Demonstrate Git commands in a terminal confidently
  • Navigate GitHub.com and perform all core actions
  • Create and manage Issues and Projects for planning
  • Submit pull requests and conduct code reviews
  • Configure repository protection rules
  • Create releases with semantic versioning
  • Use GitHub CLI for command-line workflows
  • Explain appropriate workflows for different team scenarios
  • Complete the Beginner Phase Milestone Project
